docs.title: Homework Assignments
docs.text:
There will be homework assignments throughout the course. The homework assignments are mostly going to be implemented in Python and its related packages. The homework assignments will be on

  1. initial prototyping,
  2. kinematics,
  3. dynamics,
  4. parameter identification,
  5. design optimization,
  6. prototyping and testing.

Individual assignments are intended to introduce concepts discussed in class whereas the team projects are intended to reinforce the students on the concepts.

docs.title: Assignment Overview
docs.text: The goal of this assignment is to learn about you, your background, and your interests and abilities.

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text: 1. Fill out this survey

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The purpose of this assignment is to develop your knowledge and understanding of rapid prototyping techniques and the kinematics of folded systems

docs.title: Part 1: Popup Book (Due in class Monday, April 29)
docs.text:
1. Read the entire assignment before starting.
  2. Read this paper[1]. Look through other online sources you can find, including the book by Birmingham [2], or google.
  3. From these initial sources, try to learn more about the mechanisms using Google Scholar.
  4. Make a table of three different origami-inspired or popup mechanisms used in research, including an image, URL, citation reference (eg [1]), and short description. (All citations must be included in your references section.) This should be submitted with your final submission, but it does not need to be brought to class.
  5. Make a popup greeting card that uses the opening and closing of the card to "erect" the mechanism. In other words, when you open the book, your mechanism unfolds, revealing its final shape.
    • the card should be composed of at least two different mechanism types and three total sub-mechanisms.
    • Connect at least two of your mechanisms together in series.
    • Connect at least two of your mechanisms together in parallel.
    • You should use at least one planar and one spherical mechanism in your popup book. Identify which is which. If you don't know the difference, ask in the forum on Canvas
    • Focus on demonstrating your knowledge of the mechanisms you found, rather than showing complex tesselations or repeating patterns of the same thing.

1. Bring to class on Monday, April 29. The remainder of the assignment is due by the date indicated on Canvas.

docs.title: Part 2: Document your Prototype
docs.text:
1. Take 3 photos of your final popup book in open, closed, and midway positions. The simple example from above is shown in those three states, for example. Over-draw each joint in a vector drawing program to highlight joint locations in the image.

  2. Take a video of your popup book opening and closing, and post to YouTube.

  3. Include the table created above in your final report

docs.title: Part 3: Planar Mechanism
docs.text:
1. Make a simple, unique, planar, four-bar linkage using stiff paper, cardstock, or cardboard. None of the sides of this linkage should be the same length. Remember, a planar mechanism is a mechanism whose motion can be fully captured by a planar cross section of the device, as seen below:

    Note: There is no requirement to reinforce or stiffen the device for the purposes of this assignment, as long as the cardstock you use is stiff enough to not bend noticeably in your photos.

  2. Document your physical prototype.

    1. Label each of the physical links as link A, link B, link C, and link D.
    2. Measure and note the length of each link.
    3. Take pictures of your device from the top, side, and other oblique angles, ensuring that link labels are visible.
    4. Take pictures of your device from the side at both limits of its range of motion, including at least two intermediate configurations. You will be performing your analysis at these configurations.

    5. Measure the angles of each joint in each configuration, using the photos you took (from the side) to identify each of your mechanism's joint angles and collect them in a table. You will use these values in part 3.

      • You can use any software such as photoshop, GIMP, inkscape, solidworks, etc to measure angles.
      • It is not necessary to recreate the linkage using a vector-drawing program.

      Please ensure consistency in the definition of your angles and rotations and in the values you measure. Define your incremental rotation angle to be considered positive when it is defines the angle from the proximal link to the distal link, with the axis pointing out of the page, using the right hand rule.

    6. Measure the range of motion of your device. How far can you rotate the input in the positive and negative direction without bending any links or having links physically interfere with each other? How far does your output move? At what points or between what links does your device interfere with itself first? Justify your measurements with the photos taken previously.

  3. Create a diagram of your four-bar linkage in the plane in one of its intermediate configurations, ensuring consistency with the physical prototype.

    1. Define the base link. Identify the "grounded" base link of the device as a reference frame for defining the moving distal links. The simplest and most straightforward way to think of the base link is the link that is permanently attached to the floor or table.
    2. Define the input. You will need one input link (per the device's degrees of freedom) to fully define the position of the output. The input link should be adjacent to the base link, and the angle defined between the base and input link should be considered the "input angle".
    3. Define the output of the mechanism by selecting a point \(p_{out}\) on a different link. This output point might be a point of interest for your popup-book, for example.
    4. Identify the relative rotation angles between neighboring frames.
    5. Label each of the physical links as link A, link B, link C, and link D.
    6. Label the frames on each link. Each link should be considered to contain its own rigid reference frame. Draw a pair of orthogonal unit vectors on the plane of the link and identify these vectors (eg \(\hat{a}_x\), \(\hat{a}_y\), \(\hat{b}_z\)) on the links

docs.title: Part 4: Code Implementation
docs.text:
In this section you will compose the transforms and kinematics for your mechanism and plot it using the resulting vectors

  1. Create a new jupyter/colab notebook. In the first cell, paste in the kinematics code you began in class for defining rotations and/or quaternions.
  2. Define the appropriate 3D local rotational transform for each link, describing the rotation between the closest proximal reference frame and its own.
    • Use a Python function to create quaternions or rotation matrices with a rotation axis and joint angle you supply.
    • For the joint axis and joint angle, use the axis you defined earlier, and the angle you measured in previous steps, to ensure consistency between your description and your math.
  3. Compose the 3D global rotational transform for each link's reference frame from the base frame you previously defined.

  4. Define the 3D vectors that describe the vector beetween two points on each link, the first point being a point located on / along the proximal joint axis, the second being a point located on / along the distal joint axis, using the unit vectors of the local reference frame that are attached to that link. For the output link, create the local vector that points to \(p_{out}\)

  5. Define the two global 3D vectors that describe the position of the end effector position (\(p_{out_1}\) and \(p_{out_2}\) in my drawing) from the origin (0,0,0) along each of the two possible paths, using only base frame unit vectors.

    It is reasonable to describe two separate chains to the same point, and to supply successive rotations to each. These two points may not actually touch due to measurement error.

  6. Compute the "error" between your two calculations for \(p_{out}\), using the definition for length of a vector.

  7. Using matplotlib, plot the mechanism in its computed position along both paths, from proximal to distal. Do not plot the gap between the same point via separate open loop chains.

    You may either use a 2D or 3D plot, but the computations leading up to this should be in 3D, and consistent with the device prototyped above.

docs.title: Part 5: Discussion
docs.text:
Please discuss each of the following points. Your answer should be a short passage consisting of multiple sentences.

  1. Comment on how well your mechanism as plotted in part 3 matched the device you prototyped in part 2.
  2. Identify potential pitfalls or sources of error that could lead to differences between the two.

docs.title: Submission
docs.text:
Please include a Jupyter notebook and pdf of the following:

  1. Detailed description of the completed steps above (included as markdown blocks accompanying any chunks of related code)
    • Images and screenshots should be included inline within the ipython notebook
  2. Code used in solving the assignment (inline in the report in code blocks), along with descriptions detailing your approach.
    • requested plots and figures should be included inline
  3. Detailed answers to the discussion questions asked alongside all steps, as well as the explicit discussion questions at the bottom.

docs.text:
• Please follow the "Submission Best Practices" document posted on the course website.
  • This assignment should be submitted to Canvas as a jupyter notebook (.ipynb) file and pdf.
    • Please ensure that the .ipynb code is fully compiled and runs without error in its entirety. This can be done by opening the file in your browser / editor of choice, and by selecting "Restart and Run All" (or similar).
    • Ensure the pdf is legible and makes appropriate use of page scaling to ensure answers are not cut off, truncated, or spread across multiple pages -->

What Worked Well Last year

  • Being Precise
    • If you cut by hand, use a straightedge and x-acto.
    • Consider using a laser cutter to score sheet or weaken.
  • Making things out of one piece
  • Making hinges with flexible materials
    • Consider taping or reinforcing joints.
  • Making links with stiff materials
  • Scoring hinges
  • Practicing

What didn't work well last year

  • flaps & slides (they catch and jam)
  • small features
  • overlapping parts / features
  • corrugated cardboard
  • misalignments due to assembly
  • your first try
  • hysteresis
  • superglue

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The purpose of this assignment is to demonstrate your knowledge of kinematics through exemplar exercises, specifically the following content

  • Vectors and vector operations
  • The use of vectors in describing constraints
  • The creation of vector-based expressions to describe key aspects of robotic systems such as the Jacobian and to demonstrate its use
  • Key uses of the quaternion in hinged and foldable systems

docs.title: Part 1
docs.text:
\[\begin{align} \vec{v}_1=&c_1 \hat{a}_x+c_2 \hat{a}_y+c_3 \hat{a}_z\\ % \vec{v}_2=&c_4 \hat{a}_x+c_5 \hat{a}_y+c_6 \hat{a}_z\\ \vec{v}_2=&c_4 \hat{b}_x+c_5 \hat{b}_y+c_6\hat{b}_z \end{align}\]
  1. Write the expanded form of $\vec{v}_1 \cdot \vec{v}_2 $. Do not just show your answers or skip steps, show your process of expanding and simplifying each expression. You can do this by hand or in latex.

  2. Now assume you are given more information from question 1 about the relationship between the \(A\) and \(B\) reference frames. Simplify your expression for problem 3 using \(\theta=\frac{\pi}{3}\) and

    \[\sideset{^{a}}{^{b}}R (\theta) = \begin{array}{c|ccc}& b_x& b_y& b_z\\ \hline a_x &\cos{\theta} &0& \sin{\theta} \\ a_y &0&1&0\\ a_z & -\sin{\theta} & 0& \cos{\theta} \end{array} \]

  3. Write an equation that constrains \(\vec{w}\) to be \(l\) units away from the line that includes \(\vec{u}\) and \(\vec{v}\).

  4. Regarding question 3

    1. how many degrees of freedom does vector \(\vec{w}\) have?
    2. What joint type is this equivalent to?

docs.title: Part 2
docs.text:
Given the following robot:

  1. Write the two incremental rotation tables, $\sideset{^{a}}{^{b}}R (\theta_1) $ and $\sideset{^{b}}{^{c}}R (\theta_2) $.
  2. Find the vector \(\vec{r}\), describing the end effector's position in terms of each link's "native" unit vectors.
  3. Express \(\vec{r}\) into base frame components (\(\hat{a}_x\), \(\hat{a}_y\), and \(\hat{a}_z\)).

  4. Determine the Jacobian, \(J\), for the end effector by finding \(\dot{y} = \left.\frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}\right|_A\) in terms of \(\dot{\theta}=\begin{bmatrix}\dot{\theta}_1 \\ \dot{\theta}_2\end{bmatrix}\), such that (at \(\theta_1=\frac{\pi}{6}\),\(\theta_2=\frac{\pi}{6},l_b=1,l_c=1\)),

    \[\dot{y} = J\dot{\theta}\]

    You may use either a numerical or symbolic approach

  5. Now say the robot's joints move at a rate of \(\dot{{\theta}} = \begin{bmatrix}2.2\\3.1\end{bmatrix}\). What is the velocity of the end-effector (in the same configuration as the previous problem)?

  6. Now say a force of \(\vec{f}=500\hat{a}_x+1.7\hat{a}_y+3.2\hat{a}_z\) N is exerted on the end-effector, with \(\theta_1=\frac{\pi}{2}\),\(\theta_2=0,l_b=1,l_c=1\). What torques are required at each joint to hold the robot in static equilibrium?
  7. Please explain why, given a force of 500N in the x direction, the torques at the joints are so low.

docs.title: Part 3
docs.text:
The following questions are related to the spatial (3D) origami-inspired mechanism above. Pay attention to the following notes:

  • Each vertex's initial position (in the base frame) is indicated
  • Each joint is indicated by a red line between vertices
  • The gray triangle is considered fixed to the ground

Questions:

  1. How many degrees of freedom does the mechanism have? Please justify your answer.
  2. Define and label a reference frame for each rigid body.

  3. Draw and label the vectors \(\vec{r}_{XY}\) indicating each joint's direction from frame \(X\) to frame \(Y\).

    initially this problem said \(\hat{r}_{i}\); either notation is accepted.

  4. Write down the unit quaternions \(r_{XY}\) that describe the half-angle rotations about each joint from \(X\) to \(Y\). Use variables \(\alpha_i\) to describe the magnitude of the rotation about each \(\vec{r}_i\), respectively.

    Don't forget to ensure that your quaternion meets the constraints required for unit quaternions.

  5. Find two independent vectors representing point \(\vec{f}\) -- in terms of joints that contribute to its position -- from the base frame to \(\vec{f}\).

  6. Express those two vectors as pure quaternions, in the base frame.
  7. Define \(m\) constraint equations
  8. Calculate the total degrees of freedom as a function of: (number of joints) - (number of constraints). Does this match your intuition from earlier? Why or why not?
  9. Optional and Ungraded: Implement the steps required to plot this device in matplotlib in a physically-consistent configuration with non-zero joint angles.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The purpose of this assignment is to acquaint you with the concepts of creating and using a dynamic simulation for answering questions

docs.title: Part 1: Constraints revisited
docs.text:
The purpose of this exercise is to get experience working with constraints in MuJoCo, and how the parameters work. You will create a planar four-bar linkage in mujoco, adapted from the double pendulum code shared in the dynamics 1 handout.

  1. Define a total of five links in series with each other. From proximal to distal they should be labeled "A", "B", "C", "D", and "Ap". "A" should be grounded and the other four should initially align with the x asis of your A frame.
    • Ensure your xml is in "degree" mode
    • Add a small amount of damping to each joint (damping=.1)
    • set the mass of each body to 1 (defining mass inside the <geom> is sufficient)
    • all the links should be a length of 1 for this exercise.
    • You can ground your \(A\) link by removing the first hinge from the kinematic chain.
    • Disable contact in your simulation. This will help body A and Ap move through each other in order to establish the right constraints.

  2. Add the following code to the bottom of the xml, right above the </mujoco> line. What happens? Does this look like a four-bar?

    <equality>
    <weld name="weld1" active="true" body1="A" body2="Ap" relpose="0 0 0 1 0 0 0" anchor="0 0 0" />
</equality>

  3. change axisangle="0 1 0 0" to axisangle="0 1 0 -80" for bodies "B" thru "Ap". Display the pose at t=0.

    1. Report the joint angles at t=0. Based on our in-class discussion, explain why the values are what they are.
    2. Show the 3D rendering at t=3.
    3. Now describe what happens when you run the step through the simulation. How is this different from your first try?

  4. Finally, revert axisangle="0 1 0 -80" to axisangle="0 1 0 0" for bodies "B" thru "Ap". After the line that performs a resetData(), insert the following line:

    data.qpos = numpy.array([-math.pi*80/180,-math.pi*80/180,-math.pi*80/180,-math.pi*80/180])

    Describe what happens

  5. Play with the relpose and anchor terms. What happens when you use:

    1. relpose="1 1 1 1 0 0 0" anchor="1 1 1"
    2. relpose=".5 0 0 1 0 0 0" anchor="0 0 0"
    3. relpose="0 0 0 .866 0 -.5 0" anchor="0 0 0"
    4. relpose="0 0 0 .866 0 -.5 0" anchor=".5 0 0"

    Supply an image at t=3 for each of these cases, and explain in your own words what you see for each case. Using these examples, please explain what the first three terms of relpose represent, what the last four terms of relpose represent, and what the three terms of anchor represent.

docs.title: Part 2: Templates
docs.text:
The purpose of this exercise is to learn how to re-run simulations repeatedly with different model parameters. You will be using this approach to find match the values in your simulation to this dataset.

If you have not yet, refresh your knowledge of string formatting in Python.

  • https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#str.format
  • https://docs.python.org/3/library/string.html#formatstrings

Then, using the double pendulum code shared in the dynamics 1 handout as a starting point,

  1. Ensure the following parameters are set:
    1. Mass of each body is 1
    2. Timestep is set to .001
    3. Stiffness and damping (parameters k and b) are defined for each joint to be 10 and 1, respectively.
    4. Run the code and plot the joint positions over three seconds.
  2. Now, modify the xml to act as a template variable, so that all the damper and spring values in the model can be replaced by two variables, b and k, respectively.
    1. Generate the xml variable from the template variable using the python format() function, with k=10 and b=1. Re-run the simulation and confirm that the output matches your original results.
  3. Load the dataset and check the initial values of q and w. Set the initial values of your simulation to match the dataset.
  4. Move the code required to define and run a single simulation into a function that takes two parameters: b and k. It should output two variables: t and q, your time vector and your joint vector.
  5. Calculate the mean squared error between the joint position vector q and the value for q found in the dataset over each time step from t=0s to 3s.

  6. Create a for loop that iterates over

    \[(k_i,b_j), \text{ } k_i=10,20,30,\ldots,100, \text{ }b_j=1,\ldots,10\]

    and finds the total error over the whole simulation run per stiffness and damping \((k_i,b_j)\) pair.

  7. Plot the error as a function of \(k_i\) and \(b_j\), and identify the values of \(k_i\) and \(b_j\) that result in the smallest error.

  8. What have we just done by hand? What steps would you have to do to automate this better using built-in functions already provided in Python or its packages?

docs.title: Project Assignment 1
docs.text:
The purpose of this assignment is to describe and explain up your real-world characterization exercise from last week. Depending on your group this would have been either the motor characterization exercise or the beam bending exercise.

The following team assignment may be completed and submitted as a group on Canvas. Please work with your group to complete all parts.

docs.title: Part 1: Data Collection
docs.text:
1. Write up the steps you took in class to collect data.
  2. Discuss all the shortcuts and deficiencies of your experimental setup, and things you could do to improve or simplify or streamline the data collection process.
    1. What tools could serve you better in holding materials, providing more stable and repeatable setups?
    2. What techniques could create higher video quality?
    3. How might you reduce or factor in the distortion caused by lenses? What kind of calibration would you perform?
    4. Would different sensing technologies could replace or augment the approach taken?
  3. Discuss the extraction of point data from video using tracker.
    • After using tracker, you should be able to identify other deficiencies of your data collection procedure. Specifically focus on how you might adapt your experimental process to:
      • Reduce the effects of motion blur
      • Use the features of tracker more effectively
      • Eliminate as many manual processing steps as possible

docs.title: Part 2: Modeling
docs.text:
1. Introduce the code you used to fit your model, inline with the jupyter notebook code you used.

    This should be adapted from the code shared with you, but through your discussion you should include all the steps taken to adapt it based on the slightly different assumptions used in your experiment.

    Discuss the model itself. How granular / detailed did you make it?

  2. Show your results and discuss any problems or issues with the conclusions

  3. Discuss any modeling issues and how you might improve your model in the future.

docs.title: Part 3: Sharing (Ungraded, but not Optional)
docs.text: Now share your results with the other team. This includes all original experimental data as well as modeling results. Sharing can be done by uploading your completed assignment as a zip file to the sharing folder.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The purpose of this assignment is to design, build, and simulate your final robot.

This assignment may be completed and submitted as a group. Please work with your group to complete all parts.

docs.title: Part 1: Define the System Model
docs.text: Produce a final dynamic model in Mujoco that adapts the exemplar robot notebooks shown in class to your final geometry, material properties (joint stiffness and beam stiffness), and actuator characteristics. Ensure your model includes some aspect of material compliance / flexibility and motor behavior somewhere in your system, and that you have made it possible to vary at least one design parameter of interest. Plot performance of the model in a way that can be correlated to a real-life experiment.

docs.title: Part 2 (Optional and Ungraded): Plan and Execute the Manufacturing
docs.text:
1. Based on one of the robots shared in class, define the mechanism that will be fabricated. This may be done in tools like inkscape, autocad, or solidworks as a flat sketch, but the results should be a .dxf or .svg file, with colors indicating hinges, cuts and any other important geometry as color coded lines. Please provide a legend for each color as you have defined it.
  2. Use the this file you created to extract joint lines and compute the multi-layer manufacturing process.
  3. Laser cut the geometry on each layer.
  4. Laminate the layers together

docs.title: Part 3 (Optional and Ungraded): Assemble your prototype
docs.text:
1. Assemble your robot's kinematics from
  2. Attach servos and test functionality.
  3. Connect ESP32 and program the gait
  4. Run the robot and record its behavior (qualitative) and performance(quantitative) as a function of the metric you determined earlier.

docs.title: Part 4: Improve your Model
docs.text:
Using your Mujoco Model as-built prototype, vary one or more design parameter(s) in your model prototpye to study the impact of changing it on your robot's performance.

  • This may require you to develop an XML template and regenerate your model programmatically as needed
  • Select a metric that describes the performance of your robot. This may be robot speed, overal distance traveled in a particular direction, efficiency, etc.

  • Add <site>/<sensor> elements as needed to track any additional variables necessary for computing robot performance.

    This isn't necessary for joint position / speed variables, which use the qpos() or qvel() methods for accessing them.

  • Create a relatively granular sweep of your performance metric over the range of design variable(s) and plot your results.

  • Select an approach to further maximize your selected performance metric. This may be an optimization / minimization function, or a (finer-grained) global approach.

docs.title: Submission
docs.text:
Your final project should follow the following steps; it should do so in two formats: a report and video.

  1. Walk us through the jupyter notebook file you based your robot on. Include all assumptions or simplifications you made and differences you might reasonably expect from real-world conditions.
  2. Discuss the design variable(s) you decided to study and why.
  3. Discuss how you used global parameter sweep(s) and optimization to understand performance as a function of your selected design variable, and why you took that approach.
  4. Present your results and discuss, using your intuition, why you believe your result aligns with what might be expected on the physical device or not.

docs.title: Report
docs.text: Your final report can be submitted as a final jupyter notebook file that mixes report text with modeling and coding. Please focus on a detailed walkthrough of the steps you took and a thorough discussion.

docs.title: Video
docs.text:
Your final video should walk us through all aspects of this assignment. It can be in the form of a powerpoint video with narration mode on that you save as an .mp4.

  • It should be no longer than 5 minutes

docs.title: Course Description
docs.text:
• Design and manufacturing of flexible mechanisms.
  • Biomechanics and bioinspiration.
  • Kinematics and dynamics of robots and mechanisms.
  • Mechanics and the effects of compliance on robot dynamics.
  • Design optimization and system identification for flexible robots.
  • Experimental validation of flexible robots.

docs.title: Course Objectives
docs.text:
Having successfully completed this course, the student will learn the following:

  1. Using bio-inspired approaches in the development and design of mechanisms
  2. Understanding the kinematic relationships between forces and motion for rigid mechanical systems
  3. Understanding the relationships between force and deflection in flexible systems
  4. Being able to build and use physics-based models for understanding the dynamic motion of robotic systems
  5. Understanding how the limitations of fabrication processes translate to design constraints and guidelines for flexible systems.
  6. The basics of data collection and experiment design
  7. How to use optimization approaches in solving a robotics design problem.

docs.title: Objectives and Outcomes Coverage
docs.text:
This course primarily contributes to program outcomes that develop student abilities to:

  • An ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics.
  • An ability to apply engineering design to produce solutions that meet specified needs with consideration of public health, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural, social, environmental, and economic factors.
  • An ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences.
  • An ability to function effectively on a team whose members together provide leadership, create a collaborative and inclusive environment, establish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.
  • An ability to develop and conduct appropriate experimentation, analyze and interpret data, and use engineering judgment to draw conclusions.
  • An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using appropriate learning strategies.

docs.title: Incoming Skillsets
docs.text:
You should be familiar with:

  • Programming fundamentals, ideally in a scripted language like Python or Matlab.
  • Linear algebra, differential equations, calculus, trigonometry, vectors, etc.
  • manual and rapid prototyping techniques, and if not, willing to learn.

docs.title: Grading
docs.text: Item % Individual Assignments and Quizzes 60% Team Project 40% Total 100%

docs.title: Grading Rubric
docs.text:
Assignments and Projects will be graded according to the following rubric. The following is a general description of what each point value means in this course:

Description Points % Exceeds Expectations. Shows superior effort, quality, mastering of the concepts. Innovation in the execution of submitted work. Documentation is publication-ready. 5 100 Above expectations. Demonstrates full understanding of the problem, and solution is well executed, documented, and presented. 4 85 Meets expectations. Minor mistakes are present, but student demonstrates a general understanding of the concepts. Documentation present but perhaps not comprehensive. 3 70 Below expectations. Some effort shown, though there may be serios flaws in analysis or execution. Documentation lacking in certain areas. 2 55 Fails to meet minimum expections. Minimal effort shown. Does not show understanding and may not have thought through their methods. Documentation is lacking substance, clarity, completeness, evidence of effort. 1 40 Not submitted, illegible, not readable, not properly linked 0 0 ## Assignments vs. Projects
  • Individual assignments introduce concepts discussed in class
  • Team projects aim to reinforce concepts.
  • Students will work in Project teams of 3-4 people
  • Assignments and projects will rely on the use of Python and its packages.
  • Quizzes will occur as needed.

docs.title: Individual Assignments
docs.text: There will be 6 individual assignments throughout the course. These assignments will be focused on (1) initial prototyping, (2) kinematics, (3) dynamics, (4) parameter identification, (5) design optimization, (6) prototyping and testing. The individual assignments are intended to introduce concepts discussed in class whereas the team projects are intended to reinforce the students on the concepts.

docs.title: Team Project
docs.text: There will be four project assignments. These assignments involve the design of a robotic mechanism, starting with an idealized kinematic analysis of the design and its dynamic modeling. Later assignments will include the effects of flexibility in the robot dynamics, the planning, fabrication, and testing of flexible robot components, and its final validation. The students will make a demo video of their second project at the end of the semester. Students will work in groups of 3-4.

docs.title: Quizzes
docs.text: I reserve the right to add up to 2 quizzes without notice, if attendance and work quality are suffering. Quizzes are each worth the equivalent to one individual assignment.

docs.title: Exams
docs.text: There are no exams in this course.

docs.title: In-Class Coding Labs and Tutorial Sessions
docs.text:
Some portion of class time will be set aside for students to apply the methods introduced in class. In these tutorials, the students will model and simulate robots in Python environment, apply optimization techniques, and perform system identification, amongst other topics.

Students are expected to come to the lab and tutorial sessions with a laptop capable of running Python.

docs.title: Attendance
docs.text:
Attendance will be taken during lectures and labs. Excused absences will be given for documented medical reasons or official university-related travel. Documentation must be in the form required by the university (doctor report, travel ticket, etc.).

It must also be noted that attendance is extremely important; irregular attendance typically results in poor or mediocre performance.

docs.title: Late Penalities
docs.text:
Each concept in this class builds on the last, so failing to turn in an assignment on time affects you and your teammates.

  • It is your responsibility to get in touch with the instructor regarding any questions before assignments are due.
  • Late submissions will lose one letter grade(10%) for every day they are late.
  • Any submission more than four days late will receive a zero.

docs.title: Course Honor Code
docs.text: Plagiarism and cheating are not acceptable in this course. I will follow the university's policies and academic honor code in enforcing any perceived violations.

docs.title: Specific Rules
docs.text:
• Do your own work for individual assignments and tests.
  • Include the your sources of inspiration within assignments and projects. This will help grow the list of cool references, but more importantly, help distinguish inspiration from wholesale plagarism.
  • Keep code/text/information you use from outside sources separate from your own original content (through the use of separate folders, for example). Make it explicit what is yours and what is not.
  • Include all the licenses or copyright statements as required by the things you reuse. This will make your own code more reuseable for yourself and potentially others in the future.
  • See the academic handbook for more info.

docs.title: How to Succeed in this Course
docs.text:
• Attend all class sessions.
  • Complete all pre-class preparation assignments and reading.
  • Complete all post-class follow up assignments and reading.
  • Participate in tutorial sessions and office hours.
  • Check your school email regularly.
  • Log in to the course websites at least once each week.
  • Communicate proactively with your instructor.
  • Create a study schedule so that you don’t fall behind on assignments.

docs.title: AI and the Use of chat-GPT
docs.text:
Large-language models like ChatGPT will become an ever-more important tool going forward in the field of engineering. This class, however, is intended to teach you to use both your own knowledge and the tools around you to solve problems related to flexible robotics. In this class it is expected that you will do your own thinking, analysis, and learning. It is also important to cite your references when using someone else's work. Therefore, whenever you use chatGPT or a similar large-language model in completing assignments or projects, you must indicate what it was used for. You should also include the full text of the query(ies). The citation can be included as a footnote, citation, or directly in your assignment text. Queries can be attached at the end of the assignment.

It is inappropriate to use chatGPT or other AI-related tools in quizzes and exams.

docs.title: Schedule
docs.text: The class schedule can be found on the course website. It is subject to change, and will be updated regularly. It is your responsibility to keep track of all due dates and times.

docs.title: Tentative Course Outline (might change depending on the progression of the course)
docs.text: Week/Date Topics Covered Week 1 Introduction, flexible robot history, flexible robot fabrication methods Week 1 Biomechanics: muscles, workloops, inverted pendulum vs. SLIP, gaits, scaling laws. Manufacturing introduction Week 2 Biomechanics: bioinspiration in robotics. Kinematics: introduction, DoF, joints, linkages, mechanisms Week 2 Project I topics discussions. Kinematics: Jacobians, vectors and vector operations, loop closure equations Week 3 Kinematics: rotations and reference frames, constraints. Week 3 Dynamics: dyads, dyadics, mass and inertia, energy Week 4 Dynamics: forces, mass and inertia, triple pendulum example, project I presentations Week 4 Dynamics: modeling Week 5 Mechanics and compliance. Week 5 Fabrication tutorial. Manufacturing. Week 6 Manufacturing computation and algorithms in Python. Week 6 Tutorials (Tracker, FEA, Mass and inertia and Solidworks, Pseudo-rigid body modeling) Week 7 Design optimization and final prototyping. Week 7 Experimental validation. Student demonstrations.

docs.title: Submission Best Practices
docs.text: This page details how to prepare assignments for submission. The "Submission" section of your assignment should provide the details for what format and where to submit assignments. This document should be used in conjunction with each assignment to ensure that all required files are submitted, and in the correct format.

docs.title: General Document Preparation
docs.text:
When answering questions, don't just answer the question, phrase the answer in a complete sentence which includes what the question asked. For example:

Question:

What is the sum of one and one?

Response

Two

Instead, provide context and detail in your answer, like this:

Question:

What is the sum of one and one?

Response:

Our group found that the sum of one and one is two. This was verified in two ways. First we ran a simulation using the following code....

Second we ran an experiment where we took M&M's and counted how many there were when we put one next to another. We found the answer was two across ten experiments with a mean of 2 and standard deviation of 0.1 M&M's. We attribute the error to the fact that Maxwell ate one.

This will help when you transition from assignment reports to your final report. Please still include the question or at least the question number before your answer for the convenience of the grader.

docs.title: Figures & Tables
docs.text:
Please include figures and tables inline with the text so that it is easy to find when referring to it in the text. Figures may be composed of images, data-centric plots, or annotated graphics. Here are some other guidelines:

  • Use detailed subtitles.
  • Utilize figure numbers when referring to them in the main body of the text. Utilize color schemes in figures which print well in color as well as black and white.

docs.title: CAD renderings or screenshots
docs.text:
• Photo-realistic renderings look better than screenshots, but take longer to create. These will be required for final reports and presentations.
  • Change background to white before taking screenshots.
  • utilize multiple standard orientations (top, right, iso) in order to provide a clear picture of your design.
  • include source CAD files as specified below

docs.title: Code Snippets
docs.text: • Code Snippets: you may include useful code snippets inline as long as they are well commented and referred to in the main body of the text, but source code must always be supplied in the manner specified below.

docs.title: References
docs.text: Literary References must be used in body of your text, and supplied in a bibliography section at the end. ** Use IEEE format.** Reference managers such as Mendeley or Zotero can do this formatting for you automatically.

docs.title: Hyperlinks
docs.text: Plain text, unformatted hyperlinks should not be supplied in the main body of reports and documents. If you wish to use a hyperlink in the main body of a document, please use a footnote to the full-text link1. Please do not use masked links in text.

docs.title: File Format-specific instructions
docs.text: Different assignments may require you to submit documents and supporting files in a number of different formats. Please see below for the submission guidelines for each file type

docs.title: PDFs
docs.text:
If the document is requested as a pdf, produce a single, monolithic pdf with all document parts such as figures, tables, images, code snippets and references included inline.

When submitting pdf-based submissions, you should only attach two files: 1) the monolithic pdf, and 2) any supporting files in a separate .zip file.

docs.title: Webpages
docs.text:
If the document is requested as a web page, produce your site using markdown or html with all document parts such as figures, tables, images, and references embedded inline. Inline files(media files, data, etc...) will need to be separately uploaded to the web host as well. Supporting files may be uploaded to the host and linked from the web page. You may use external sites to render uploaded jupyter notebooks rather than converting them to markdown, if desired. See the tutorials for more information

When submitting web-based assignments, submit the link to the web page and the underlying github repository. Ensure that any supporting files in are linked from within the web page and render completely from a separate computer.

docs.title: Jupyter Notebooks
docs.text:
Jupyter submissions are convenient because they permit code, reporting, figures, photos, etc all to be housed within one dynamic document. This format is highly encouraged or required for many assignments.

When you submit a Jupyter notebook, ensure that 1) the notebook has been fully compiled before submitting, and 2) that any external files are included either as a separate .zip file or, if the file is to be added to the website, uploaded to your web server. The notebook can be recompiled by opening the file in the jupyter browser and in the top jupyter menu selecting "Kernel" --> "Restart and Run All".

If posting jupyter notebooks to a web page, there are two options: 1) download your jupyter notebook as a markdown file (or .zip) and upload that document, or link to the original .ipynb file using an external service.

If submitting jupyter assignments, Submit the source .ipynb file. Ensure that any supporting files are included in a separate .zip file and are also separately uploaded. Include your name or team # at the beginning of all notebooks.

docs.title: Other Code (python, microcontroller, etc.)
docs.text: Zip up all files used to run your code (outside of standard packages). Indicate any other packages you installed which are required to run it, where you got, them, how you installed them (conda, pip, etc), and what version you installed. The professor and TA should be able to run your code using the instructions and files provided. After finishing the code, print output as your name in the last line before submission.

docs.title: CAD
docs.text: Utilize Solidworks' File --> "Pack and Go" Feature to include all files required to view parts and assemblies into a single zip file. Drawings in .dxf format must be exported to .pdf format and submitted separately. Make sure you include your name or team name.

docs.title: Videos
docs.text:
You may be asked to submit or post recorded presentations or experiments as videos. Due to space limitations, please embed these videos as embedded YouTube videos in web pages or link to their YouTube pages in .pdf documents. Please make sure the video is "unlisted" rather than "private" ("public" is also ok but is not required).

When taking videos, try to follow these general rules of thumb:

  • Avoid messy background scenes. Try to utilize blank backgrounds, or ensure the background does not distract from the action in the foreground
  • Reduce unwanted noise in the scene. Turn down music, avoid picking up background conversations, etc.
  • Utilize a tripod if possible. Stay away from handheld video
  • Use landscape rather than portrait aspect ratio.

docs.title: Images
docs.text: • If you include an image of a hand-made origami element, over-draw each joint in a vector drawing program to highlight joint locations in the image.

docs.title: Slides & Presentations
docs.text:
Slides may be submitted in .pptx or pdf form. If submitting .pptx files, beware of linked (rather than embedded) videos, unembedded fonts, missing codecs, etc. I can't play -- or grade -- what's not included.

If submitting pdf files of presentations, include any embedded videos separately as indicated in the videos section.

docs.title: Kinematics
docs.text:
branch of physics and a subdivision of classical mechanics concerned with the geometrically possible motion of a body or system of bodies without consideration of the forces involved (i.e., causes and effects of the motions).

Britannica, The Editors of Encyclopaedia. "kinematics". Encyclopedia Britannica, Invalid Date, https://www.britannica.com/science/kinematics. Accessed 24 January 2022.

docs.title: Kinetics
docs.text:
branch of classical mechanics that concerns the effect of forces and torques on the motion of bodies having mass. Authors using the term kinetics apply the nearly synonymous name dynamics (q.v.) to the classical mechanics of moving bodies.

Britannica, The Editors of Encyclopaedia. "kinetics". Encyclopedia Britannica, Invalid Date, https://www.britannica.com/science/kinetics. Accessed 24 January 2022.

docs.title: Mechanisms
docs.text:
• A system of parts working together in a machine; a piece of machinery.
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanism_(engineering)
  • https://languages.oup.com/google-dictionary-en/

docs.title: Linkage
docs.text:
• A type of mechanism
  • Refers to a system of rigid bodies connected by joints or links
  • Allow relative motion between them.
  • Used to transmit and control motion or force in mechanical systems.

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linkage_(mechanical)>

docs.title: Serial Mechanisms
docs.text:
• A serial mechanism, serial chain or serial linkage
  • a mechanical system in which components or links are arranged in a linear sequence,
    • Each component is connected to the one before and after it.
    • The output motion or force is transmitted through each link in a sequential manner from the input to the final output.
  • Motion or force is transmitted through a series of interconnected links or elements, typically connected by joints or hinges.
  • Each link is responsible for transmitting or transforming the input motion or force to the next link in the chain, until it reaches the final output.

docs.title: Parallel Mechanisms
docs.text:
• A mechanical system consisting of multiple interconnected links that are
  • Connected in a way that allows them to move simultaneously and independently of each other.
  • Links are arranged in a parallel configuration, meaning they share a common base and have multiple patways to one or more end-effectors.
  • Example: Delta robot. A Delta robot
    • consists of three parallel arms connected to a base
    • connected also to a distal common platform (end-effector).
    • Each arm has multiple joints that allow it to move in various directions.

docs.title: Link
docs.text: An intermediate rod or piece for transmitting force or motion; especially, a short connecting rod with a hole or pin at each end.

docs.title: Joints
docs.text:
• The connections between rigid bodies, which facilitate motion
  • Many different kinds of joints with different degrees of freedom
  • Folded devices use systems of joints

Flores, Paulo & Lankarani, Hamid. (2016). Contact Force Models for Multibody Dynamics.

docs.title: More Complex Joints
docs.text: Chase, Kenneth & Magleby, Spencer & Glancy, Charles. (2000). A Comprehensive System for Computer-Aided Tolerance Analysis of 2-D and 3-D Mechanical Assemblies. 10.1007/978-1-4615-5797-5_23.

docs.title: Joints
docs.text: https://24.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_mck6ejg15N1r0v3zro3_1280.jpg

docs.title: Degrees of Freedom
docs.text:
• Refer to the number of independent ways an object or system can move.
  • “The number of independent parameters that define its configuration or state”
  • Represents the different directions or types of motion that an object is capable of.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degrees_of_freedom_(mechanics)

docs.title: Discussion
docs.text: What are the disadvantages of developing serial-chain mechanisms with flexible materials?

docs.title: Benefits of Parallel Mechanisms
docs.text:
• Flexible robotic systems are soft
  • Flexure hinges are not perfect pin joints; they allow torsion
  • Serial mechanisms thus are exhibit a lot of non-ideal behavior
    • drooping
    • Slower & less responsive
    • Less stable behavior
    • Less precise
    • unintended drooping and twisting
    • distally mounted actuators (or more packaging to transmit joint forces to distal joints)

docs.title: Conversely, Parallel joints
docs.text:
• Increase system stiffness in directions orthogonal to motion
  • Permit actuators to be mounted proximally
  • leads to more precise and faster behavior
  • Permits the use of softer materials because overall loads are lower.

docs.text:
• Vector Operations

    • Vector Math

    • Magnitude of a Vector

    • How many numbers in a vector?

  • Vector Properties

    • Commutivity

    • Associativity

    • Distributability

    • Dot product

    • Properties of Dot Product

    • Cross Product

    • Cross Product Properties

    • Other Properties

    • No-no’s

      • Multiply a vector by another vectorright-hand-rule
      • Equate scalars to vectors
      • Use a cross product on a scalar
      • ...lots more

    • Extended Expressions: Dot Product

    • Extended Expressions: Cross Product

  • Angle Issues

    • Inner Angle

    • Cross Product

    • Specifing a Unit Vector

    • Function Domains

  • Vector Expressions

    * Help measure / express geometric relationships:

* Distance between points, lines, and planes:
    * between two points
    * between a point and a line
    * between two lines
    * between a point and a plane
* Angles between lines / planes
    * Perpendicular and Parallel Vectors
    * Interior Angles
    * Normals

    • Example: Distance between two points

    • Distance between two points

    • How do we use vector expressions in kinematics?

  • Constraints

    • Degrees of Freedom

      • What are degrees of freedom?

        • freedom of motion in a device
        • freedom of description in variables used to describe the device

    • What is a constraint?

      • Constraints establish limitations in descriptions or degrees of freedom

      • Degrees of Freedom

        • Distances
        • Perpendicular, Parallel Vectors
        • Point on a line
        • Point a distance from a line
        • Loops
      • Descriptions
        • \(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2=1\)
        • \(x = r \cos{\theta}\), \(y = r \sin{\theta}\)

    • Solved Nonlinearly

    • For most code you write, data is not differentiable or symbolic, it is numeric. Differentiation is also done numerically.

    • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_descent

    • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hill_climbing

    • Numerical Solving: Advantages and Disadvantages

      • Advantages

        • Don't need to differentiate variables, only output.
        • Faster and Easier to code

      • Disadvantages

        • Initial guess must be close.
        • Numerical solving is slow for big systems with many variables.
        • Have to solve for valid positions.
          • Continuity between solutions was not guaranteed
          • No knowledge if we skipped through a singularity.

    • More Info on minimize()

      • Many Algorithms

        • Nelder-Mead
        • Powell
        • CG
        • BFGS
        • SLSQP
        • ... many more

      • https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.minimize.html

    • Vector Description Choice

      * * Cartesian Coordinates \((x,y)\) * * Polar Coordinates \((r,\theta)\) * * State Variables

    • Counting Kinematic Equations

    • Comparison

      • Cartesian Advantages

        • Simple representation
        • Easy to represent all constraints as length of vector

      • Disadvantages

        • you can encounter "representational" singularites
        • more variables than degrees of freedom

      • Polar Advantages

        • representation matches physical meaning (structure, motors)
        • fewer representational singularities

      • Disadvantages

        • requires intuition as to how to best represent?

    • What about origami?

  • What are the ways to represent folds?

    • Cartesian
      • State Variables?
        • Vertices
      • Need constraints for ?
        • length
    • Joint axes / angles
      • State Variables?
        • Thetas
      • Need constraints for ?
        • Loops

  • Jacobians

    * A Jacobian is a matrix that collects the partial derivatives of rates of change between two vectors.  These rates of change are related by

    • Warning

      • You can't take the derivative of vectors in moving / rotating frames without accounting for that frame's motion in the base frame.

    • Physical Meaning of Jacobians

      • gears analogy

    • Torques and Forces

    • Virtual Work

  • Numerical Jacobians

    • Meaning

    • Process

  • Derivative-based Jacobians

    • Find end-effector

    • Expand

    • Take Derivative

    • Assemble the Jacobian

    • Numerical vs Symbolic

    • Advantages vs. Disadvantages

      • Speed of computation
      • Number of computations
      • Complexity of the expression
      • Alternative: Use more efficient algorithms, but solve numerically

docs.title: Comparison of terms
docs.text:
Biomechanics:

Field of study that combines biology and physics to understand how living organisms move and interact with their environment.

Bio-inspiration:

Taking inspiration from nature and using it to solve human problems or create innovative designs and technologies.

Biomimicry:

An attempt to directly copy features and morphologies seen in nature

docs.title: Work Loop
docs.text:
Another perspective of the time-based interactions between muscles the world is the "work loop"

  • Work: the energy required to move an object.
  • Walking is often considered a "limit cycle", "a periodic orbit that is a limit set of the dynamical system"
  • A work loop is a way to visualize and understand the work done on an object as it moves through a closed path or loop.

docs.title: Cost of Transport
docs.text:
\(COT = P/mgv\) (J/m/kg)

  • the smaller the COT the more energy-effective
  • different COTs depending on what "powers" are included (total, locomotion, mechanical, etc)
  • sometimes referred to as specific resistance

docs.title: Froude Number
docs.text:
\[Fr = v^2/gl\]
  • Essentially the ratio of kinetic to potential energy
  • often viewed as a dimensionless number
  • l is a characteristic leg length (often taken in running robots as the distance from the hip to the ground)
  • dynamically similar legged locomotors should exhibit equal ratios of inertial to gravitation forces for equivalent gaits

docs.title: Beautiful math in all browsers
docs.text:
MathJax is an open-source JavaScript display engine for LaTeX, MathML, and AsciiMath notation that works in all modern browsers. It was designed with the goal of consolidating the recent advances in web technologies into a single, definitive, math-on-the-web platform supporting the major browsers and operating systems. It requires no setup on the part of the user (no plugins to download or software to install), so the page author can write web documents that include mathematics and be confident that users will be able to view it naturally and easily. Simply include MathJax and some mathematics in a web page, and MathJax does the rest.

Some of the main features of MathJax include:

  • High-quality display of LaTeX, MathML, and AsciiMath notation in HTML pages

  • Supported in most browsers with no plug-ins, extra fonts, or special setup for the reader

  • Easy for authors, flexible for publishers, extensible for developers

  • Supports math accessibility, cut-and-paste interoperability, and other advanced functionality

  • Powerful API for integration with other web applications

See http://www.mathjax.org/ for additional details about MathJax, and https://docs.mathjax.org for the MathJax documentation.

docs.title: MathJax Components
docs.text:
MathJax version 3 uses files called components that contain the various MathJax modules that you can include in your web pages or access on a server through NodeJS. Some components combine all the pieces you need to run MathJax with one or more input formats and a particular output format, while other components are pieces that can be loaded on demand when needed, or by a configuration that specifies the pieces you want to combine in a custom way. For usage instructions, see the MathJax documentation.

Components provide a convenient packaging of MathJax's modules, but it is possible for you to form your own custom components, or to use MathJax's modules directly in a node application on a server. There are web examples showing how to use MathJax in web pages and how to build your own components, and node examples illustrating how to use components in node applications or call MathJax modules directly.

docs.title: What's in this Repository
docs.text:
This repository contains only the component files for MathJax, not the source code for MathJax (which are available in a separate MathJax source repository). These component files are the ones served by the CDNs that offer MathJax to the web. In version 2, the files used on the web were also the source files for MathJax, but in version 3, the source files are no longer on the CDN, as they are not what are run in the browser.

The components are stored in the es5 directory, and are in ES5 format for the widest possible compatibility. In the future, we may make an es6 directory containing ES6 versions of the components.

docs.title: Using MathJax components from a CDN on the web
docs.text:
If you are loading MathJax from a CDN into a web page, there is no need to install anything. Simply use a script tag that loads MathJax from the CDN. E.g.,

<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>

See the MathJax documentation, the MathJax Web Demos, and the MathJax Component Repository for more information.

docs.title: Hosting your own copy of the MathJax Components
docs.text:
If you want to host MathJax from your own server, you can do so by installing the mathjax package using npm and moving the es5 directory to an appropriate location on your server:

npm install mathjax@3
mv node_modules/mathjax/es5 <path-to-server-location>/mathjax

Note that we are still making updates to version 2, so include @3 when you install, since the latest chronological version may not be version 3.

Alternatively, you can get the files via GitHub:

git clone https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax.git mj-tmp
mv mj-tmp/es5 <path-to-server-location>/mathjax
rm -rf mj-tmp

Then (in either case) you can use a script tag like the following:

<script id="MathJax-script" async src="<url-to-your-site>/mathjax/tex-chtml.js"></script>

where <url-to-your-site> is replaced by the URL to the location where you moved the MathJax files above.

See the documentation for details.

docs.title: Using MathJax components in a node application
docs.text:
To use MathJax components in a node application, install the mathjax package:

npm install mathjax@3

(we are still making updates to version 2, so you should include @3 since the latest chronological version may not be version 3).

Then require mathjax within your application:

require('mathjax').init({ ... }).then((MathJax) => { ... });

where the first { ... } is a MathJax configuration, and the second { ... } is the code to run after MathJax has been loaded. E.g.

require('mathjax').init({
  loader: {load: ['input/tex', 'output/svg']}
}).then((MathJax) => {
  const svg = MathJax.tex2svg('\\frac{1}{x^2-1}', {display: true});
  console.log(MathJax.startup.adaptor.outerHTML(svg));
}).catch((err) => console.log(err.message));

Note: this technique is for node-based application only, not for browser applications. This method sets up an alternative DOM implementation, which you don't need in the browser, and tells MathJax to use node's require() command to load external modules. This setup will not work properly in the browser, even if you webpack it or bundle it in other ways.

See the documentation and the MathJax Node Repository for more details.

docs.title: Reducing the Size of the Components Directory
docs.text:
Since the es5 directory contains all the component files, so if you are only planning one use one configuration, you can reduce the size of the MathJax directory by removing unused components. For example, if you are using the tex-chtml.js component, then you can remove the tex-mml-chtml.js, tex-svg.js, tex-mml-svg.js, tex-chtml-full.js, and tex-svg-full.js configurations, which will save considerable space. Indeed, you should be able to remove everything other than tex-chtml.js, and the input/tex/extensions, output/chtml/fonts/woff-v2, adaptors, a11y, and sre directories. If you are using the results only on the web, you can remove adaptors as well.

If you are not using A11Y support (e.g., speech generation, or semantic enrichment), then you can remove a11y and sre as well (though in this case you may need to disable the assistive tools in the MathJax contextual menu in order to avoid MathJax trying to load them when they aren't there).

If you are using SVG rather than CommonHTML output (e.g., tex-svg.js rather than tex-chtml.js), you can remove the output/chtml/fonts/woff-v2 directory. If you are using MathML input rather than TeX (e.g., mml-chtml.js rather than tex-chtml.js), then you can remove input/tex/extensions as well.

docs.title: The Component Files and Pull Requests
docs.text:
The es5 directory is generated automatically from the contents of the MathJax source repository. You can rebuild the components using the command

npm run make-es5 --silent

Note that since the contents of this repository are generated automatically, you should not submit pull requests that modify the contents of the es5 directory. If you wish to submit a modification to MathJax, you should make a pull request in the MathJax source repository.

docs.title: MathJax Community
docs.text:
The main MathJax website is http://www.mathjax.org, and it includes announcements and other important information. A MathJax user forum for asking questions and getting assistance is hosted at Google, and the MathJax bug tracker is hosted at GitHub.

Before reporting a bug, please check that it has not already been reported. Also, please use the bug tracker (rather than the help forum) for reporting bugs, and use the user's forum (rather than the bug tracker) for questions about how to use MathJax.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The purpose of this module is to lead you through the process of collecting data on a flexible system and fitting its behavior to a dynamic model

docs.title: Part 1
docs.text:
Using the tracker tutorial as a starting point, adapt it for the above setup.

Note: You may work in pairs (no more than two people) to collect data in PART 1 ONLY. Part 2 must be completed on your own. Any figures, tracker projects, calculations, text, or other parts of the writeup (other than any pictures or videos collected during the experiment) must be completed individually.

  1. Cut a long, rectangular piece of cardboard, posterboard, or other rigid material you hope / plan to use in your robot design
    • The more accurate you fabricate it and measure it the better. Cut with straight lines and try to avoid notches or gouges that will create weak points.
  2. Measure the dimensions and weight of your specimen, including thickness.
    1. The more accurate your measurements the better.
    2. Consider using a calipers or micrometer to measure the material thickness accurately, in several spots.
    3. calculate the density of your material
  3. Attach a small amount of known mass to the end of your specimen.
    • Again, mount the mass as rigidly as possible. The more it moves, the harder it is to track and model.
    • Record the distance from the edge of the table to the center of the added mass. Ensure it is placed symmetrially to avoid out of plane torsional effects in the beam.
  4. Mount your specimen to a solid table, desk or other overhang as seen above
    1. Make sure the connection to the "ground" is rigid. This can be done with a heavy weight, such as many books. Tape doesn't work, it's too flexible
    2. Measure the amount of beam overhanging vs the amount attached to ground.
  5. Attach tracking markers to your scene, at the same camera depth as your experimental setup.
    1. Multiple markers, of known distances apart, will help you scale your scene later.
    2. Measure the distance between all markers.
    3. Attach at least one marker at the tip of the flexible beam.
  6. Attach your camera to the fixed/rigid frame using a tripod or fixed camera mount.
    1. Measure the distance from your camera to the center of your experiment's z-plane.

  7. Take a practice video and run it through your capture software to ensure the markers are always visible.

    1. Start recording. Use high-quality mode.
    2. Give the beam a "kick" that is measurable but not destructive (does not plastically deform your material).

    To simplify setting initial conditions, pull the device with a string displaced a fixed distance or by a known load, let it settle, then cut the string.

  8. Check your video for issues and check the tracking process in tracker

    1. Does your beam oscillate more than once before coming to rest? If not, consider adding more mass.
    2. Is it too fast for your camera to see without blurring? Consider making the beam longer or adding mass
    3. Is gravity deforming your specimen? Consider mounting your beam vertically or reducing mass.
    4. Is your specimen deforming? Consider using thicker material, or reducing the load
    5. Is it possible for tracker to see your markers? If not, use higher-contrast colors or change your lighting.
  9. Repeat this process until you have a setup that works
  10. Run your experiment with video running at least three times (to ensure you get one good video.)
    1. Track the motion of your system until it stops moving. Make sure your motion is planar.
  11. Export/save the video to your computer
  12. Using tracker, export the x-y position of all markers over time.
  13. Ignore the initial portions of the video where you are touching the setup. Only track the free motion of the system after it is disturbed.
  14. Using the base frame markers as reference points, size and rotate your data to get x-y values in SI units.
  15. Save the results as a .csv file.

docs.title: Part 2
docs.text:
Note: Complete This Part on your own.

  • Import your csv file into python

  • If your experimental data starts with the system in motion, calculate the initial velocity of your system.

    for example, by using the positions from \(t_0\) and \(t_2\), you can find the velocity at \(t_1\) Truncate your data to start at \(t_1\)

  • In mujoco, create a facsimiile of your experiment using 5 beams. As in HW3, build your simulation as a template, with the ability to insert your own values for stiffness and damping at each joint.

  • Add masses of the correct dimension and weight/density at the appropriate locations.
  • Add a site and sensor or (negligible mass) at the location of all added markers.
  • Define the initial conditions at t=0 to match the data you collected.
  • Run your simulation, plot the experimental and simulated results on the same plat, and then discuss the comparison in the simulated output to your experimental data.
  • Find the sum of squared error between your simulation and the experiment and discuss the role this measurement plays on the goodness of the fit.
  • Encapsulate the main body of your simulation and error calculation within a function, with the two inputs as stiffness and damping, and the output returned is the \(\sqrt{\sum{\text{error}^2_i}}\), such that your experiment gets re-run every time you call the function and outputs the error.
  • Use scipy.optimize.minimize() to identify the unknown stiffness and damping parameters for your material

docs.title: Submission
docs.text:
Please include a Jupyter notebook and pdf of the following:

  1. Detailed description of the completed steps above

    • Include any chunks of related code as accompanying markdown blocks.

    • Images of handwritten work, parts you've made, and screenshots should be included inline within the ipython notebook. use the following notation:

      ![alt text](path/to/your/image.jpg)

      or, if you want to access other html attributes:

      <img src="path/to/your/image.jpg" width="300px" alt="alt text here">

  2. Code used in solving the assignment (inline in the report in code blocks), along with descriptions detailing your approach.

    • requested plots and figures should be included inline
  3. Detailed answers to the discussion questions asked alongside all steps
  4. Final video(s) of the successful runs
  5. CSV files of experimental data.

docs.title: Other Notes
docs.text:
• Please follow the "Submission Best Practices" document posted on the course website.
  • This assignment should be submitted to Canvas as a jupyter notebook (.ipynb) file and pdf.
    • Please ensure that the .ipynb code is fully compiled and runs without error in its entirety. This can be done by opening the file in your browser / editor of choice, and by selecting "Restart and Run All" (or similar).
    • Ensure the pdf is legible and makes appropriate use of page scaling to ensure answers are not cut off, truncated, or spread across multiple pages -->
